awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Variable-Pressure, Field-Emission Scanning Electron Microscope for Materials Research and Education
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Description:
In supporting the acquisition of a variable-pressure, field-emission scanning electron microscope, this project enables researchers and educators in Vermont and northern New York to explore materials at the nanometer scale. Research projects spanning physics, chemistry, engineering, materials science, and geology rely on the instrument for analysis and characterization, identifying elemental composition and local crystal structure. Remote operating capabilities allow classrooms and museums in the region to perform live experiments and demonstrations. The modern instrument, with its wide-ranging capabilities, serves as a core research infrastructure for local universities and industries alike.

Technical Description:
The scanning electron microscope is equipped with secondary electron, five-segment back-scattered electron, electron backscatter diffraction, and energy dispersive spectroscopy detectors. Combined with variable-pressure and low-voltage operating modes, these detectors allow for topographic, compositional, and crystallographic characterization of delicate samples at spatial resolution of 1.2 nm. The instrument enables research projects exploring nanoporous oxide structures, organic crystals, optoelectronic devices, optical filters, metal nanowires, rheology of crustal processes, and mineral weathering.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscope (FESEM) was assembled from a Zeiss SEM and Oxford EDS and EBSD systems and installed over three dates from June to September 2019.  81 users have been trained on the FESEM, with 35% of users being women and 40% representing ethnicities other than white/Caucasian. The FESEM supports research in wide-ranging fields of materials science, including physics, chemistry, geology, mechanical-, civil-, electrical-, optical-, and biomedical-engineering. Research areas include high surface area nanoparticle films and nanofiber networks for catalysis and sensing, soil sampling, electronic and mechanical properties of crystal grain boundaries, and nanophotonic devices.  Three journal articles have been published, and six conference presentations were given using results obtained via the FESEM. In support of the education and outreach goals of the project, two major undertakings have occurred.  A graduate/upper-division undergraduate course entitled “PHYS 296B Microstructure and Surface Analysis” was developed and taught by the PI during Spring 2020 with eight enrolled students and Spring 2022 with 13 enrolled students.  The PI and co-PIs hosted the ECHO Leahy Center for Lake Champlain’s “E-team,” a group of 14 teenage volunteers with interests in science and promoting STEM education and outreach. The high school students imaged insects, feathers, coins, and other common objects in the FESEM.
